Problem:
Evaluate the implication of the Laplace transform on the behavior of an electrical circuit described by the differential equation \( L\frac{dI}{dt} + RI = V(t) \), where \( L \) is inductance, \( R \) is resistance, and \( V(t) \) represents a time-varying voltage source. The transformation applied is \( \mathcal{L}(I(t)) = \frac{\mathcal{L}(V(t))}{sL + R} \), and we analyze effects and causality with respect to this transform.

If a specific voltage function \( V(t) \) is applied to the circuit at \( t = 0 \) and allowed to evolve according to its natural dynamics represented by the differential equation, will the behavior of \( I(t) \) solely at any later time \( t = T \) be the same as predicted by the transformed equation using \( \mathcal{L}(V(t)) \)?
Explanation: The Laplace transform of the equation retains all the information about the system's dynamics under its assumptions. The transform linearly correlates with the time-domain solution of the differential equation, thus ensuring that the behavior predicted preserves causal dynamics from \( V(t) \) to \( I(t) \).
